title: Risk Monitoring & Control
description: Learn continuous risk monitoring—distinguish residual vs secondary vs new risks, trigger contingency plans, implement workarounds, and update risk register.
objectives: Distinguish between residual risks (remain after response), secondary risks (caused by response), and new risks (emerge during execution)
Apply risk audits to evaluate response effectiveness and update risk register
Recognize when to trigger contingency plans (pre-defined) vs implement workarounds (unplanned responses)
Update risk register with new ratings, closed risks, and lessons learned continuously

screens.headline: Month 3: 5 New Risks Emerged, 2 Responses Failed

visual.description: Risk dashboard showing: Original 34 risks (green/yellow/red heatmap), 5 NEW risks (purple markers), 2 risks INCREASED severity (arrows up), 3 risks CLOSED (checkmarks), risk trend line going UP.

dialogue.text: Risk planning was just the start. Now we MONITOR, REASSESS, and ADAPT. Without monitoring, risks blindside you.

screens.learningHook: Risk monitoring isn't checking boxes—it's detecting CHANGES. Risks that were yellow are now red. Mitigation that worked in Month 1 failed in Month 3. NEW risks appeared that weren't on our radar. Your job: Evaluate 5 risk monitoring situations, distinguish risk types, decide when to trigger contingency plans.

screens.title: Risk Monitoring Decisions
screens.instructions: Evaluate 5 risk situations from Month 3 of the international expansion project. Identify risk types and choose appropriate responses.

scenarios.title: Secondary Risk from Currency Mitigation
description: Original risk: Peso depreciation (70% probability, $600K impact)
Response: Purchased currency hedging contracts ($50K cost)
Result: Currency locked successfully (original risk mitigated)
BUT: Hedging contract has $25K cancellation fee if project delays >2 months
This $25K fee is a NEW risk caused by the response itself

questions.question: What is this $25K cancellation fee risk?

options.text: Accepted risk (low impact, no action needed)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Hedging created $25K cancellation fee risk—this is SECONDARY RISK (caused by response). Original currency risk was mitigated, but response introduced NEW risk that didn't exist before. Every mitigation has side effects—track secondary risks separately.
feedback.incorrect: SECONDARY RISK = New risk caused by implementing a risk response. Hedging (response) created cancellation fee risk that didn't exist before. This is NOT residual (part of original risk) or new (unrelated to original risk).

scenarios.title: Staffing Risk Probability Increased
description: Original risk: Staffing shortage in Mexico (30% probability, $300K impact)
Response: MITIGATE by partnering with local culinary school ($15K recruiting)
Contingency plan: If probability exceeds 50%, activate temp agency contract ($45K)
Month 3 update: Culinary school yielded only 2 candidates (need 8)
Probability NOW: 60%

options.text: Continue with mitigation, wait for more candidates
Trigger contingency plan (activate temp agency contract)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Staffing probability 60% exceeded 50% trigger threshold—activate temp agency contract immediately. Contingency plans aren't optional—they're pre-approved TRIGGERS. When threshold is hit, execute.
feedback.incorrect: CONTINGENCY PLAN = Pre-defined response triggered when risk threshold exceeded. Probability 60% > 50% trigger condition—activate temp agency contract NOW. Alex doesn't need Elena's approval (contingency already budgeted).

scenarios.title: New Risk: Competitor Opened
description: Month 3: Competitor (premium F&B brand) opened in Mexico City
2 miles from Savory's planned location
This risk was NOT in original risk register (wasn't identified in C3L1)
Impact: Potential 20% revenue reduction ($360K)
No contingency plan exists (not anticipated)

questions.question: What type of risk is this, and what's the appropriate response?

feedback.correct: Perfect! NEW RISK = Emerges during execution, wasn't identified in planning. No contingency plan exists. WORKAROUND = Unplanned response to unanticipated risk. Alex must create response now (differentiate menu, accelerate marketing, adjust pricing). Risk identification never stops.
feedback.incorrect: NEW RISK emerges during project execution (wasn't on radar). No contingency plan exists—implement WORKAROUND (creative unplanned solution: differentiate menu, local influencer marketing, adjusted pricing).

scenarios.title: Regulatory Risk Response Failed
description: Original risk: Telecom regulations may change (60% probability, $800K impact)
Response: MITIGATE by lobbying regulators ($120K, escalated to Elena/CFO)
Month 3 result: Lobbying FAILED—regulations changed anyway
New compliance cost: $500K (less than original $800K, some lobbying helped)
No contingency plan exists for this scenario

options.text: Implement workaround (redesign to minimize compliance cost)

feedback.correct: Excellent! WORKAROUND = Unplanned response when risk response fails OR unanticipated risk occurs. Lobbying failed (response didn't work), no contingency exists. Alex must creatively minimize $500K cost—redesign technical solution, negotiate phased implementation. Risk responses don't always work—workarounds fill the gap.
feedback.incorrect: WORKAROUND needed when planned response FAILS. Lobbying didn't work, no contingency plan exists. Creatively minimize $500K cost: redesign technical solution to avoid most expensive compliance requirements, negotiate phased implementation.

scenarios.title: Supply Chain Risk Reduced
description: Original risk: Supplier bankruptcy (40% probability, $400K impact)
Response: MITIGATE by signing guaranteed delivery contract with penalty clause ($50K if supplier fails)
Month 3 result: Supplier signed contract
Risk probability reduced from 40% to 5% (contract provides strong protection)
BUT 5% residual risk remains—supplier could still fail despite contract

questions.question: How should Alex update the risk register?

options.text: Close the risk entirely (contract eliminated it)
Update risk rating (40% → 5%), note residual risk, continue monitoring
Mark as secondary risk (contract created new risk)
Remove from risk register (too low to track)

feedback.correct: Perfect! RESIDUAL RISK = Risk that remains AFTER response. Contract reduced risk 40% → 5%. 5% residual remains—supplier could still fail despite contract (penalty provides $50K compensation). NEVER close risks prematurely. Update register: Original 40% (red) → New 5% (yellow), note residual risk, continue monitoring.
feedback.incorrect: RESIDUAL RISK remains after response implementation. Contract reduced supplier failure from 40% to 5%—the 5% is RESIDUAL RISK. Update risk register with new rating, note residual risk, continue monitoring. 5% × $400K = $20K expected loss still material.

process: Track identified risks—monitor known risks from risk register
Identify new risks—watch for emerging risks not in original register
Analyze risk performance—Are responses working? Variance analysis
Update risk register—New ratings, closed risks, residual/secondary risks
content.frequency: WEEKLY risk reviews (integrated into project status meetings) + Monthly risk audits

blocks.title: Three Types of Risks During Execution

riskTypes.name: Residual Risks
riskTypes.definition: Risks that REMAIN after response implementation
riskTypes.example: Contract reduces supplier bankruptcy risk 40% → 5%. The 5% is residual.
riskTypes.action: Continue monitoring, may need contingency reserve

riskTypes.name: Secondary Risks
riskTypes.definition: NEW risks CAUSED BY implementing a risk response
riskTypes.example: Currency hedging creates $25K cancellation fee risk that didn't exist before
riskTypes.action: Track separately in risk register, plan responses if significant

riskTypes.name: New Risks
riskTypes.definition: Risks that EMERGE during execution, not identified in planning
riskTypes.example: Competitor opens in Mexico City (wasn't on radar during C3L1)
riskTypes.action: Implement workarounds (no contingency plans exist), update register

contingencyPlans.definition: PRE-DEFINED responses for IDENTIFIED risks, triggered when threshold exceeded
contingencyPlans.useWhen: Risk was identified in planning, contingency created, trigger condition met
contingencyPlans.example: IF staffing probability > 50%, THEN activate temp agency contract

workarounds.definition: UNPLANNED responses for risks with NO contingency plans
workarounds.useWhen: (1) Unanticipated risk emerges, OR (2) Planned response fails
workarounds.example: Lobbying failed → Redesign technical solution to minimize compliance cost
workarounds.funding: Management reserve (for unknown-unknowns) OR re-allocate budget

updateTriggers: Weekly: Risk status (probability/impact changes), new risks identified
Monthly: Risk audit results, closed risks, lessons learned
When response implemented: Note residual/secondary risks
When trigger hit: Contingency plan activation
registerSections: Closed risks: Resolved or no longer applicable
Lessons learned: What worked, what didn't

high.text: Perfect! You correctly identified secondary risk (hedging fee), triggered contingency (staffing 60% > 50%), recognized new risk (competitor) requires workaround, responded to failed mitigation (lobbying), and updated residual risk (5% supplier failure). Expert-level risk monitoring.

medium.text: Good risk monitoring understanding. Review one or two concepts: distinguishing residual vs secondary risks, or knowing when to trigger contingency vs implement workaround.

low.text: Risk monitoring requires continuous vigilance. Review: Residual = remains after response. Secondary = caused BY response. New = emerges during execution. Contingency = pre-defined trigger. Workaround = unplanned creative solution.

screens.title: Toronto Expansion Risk Monitoring
screens.context: Toronto expansion ($1.5M investment) is in Month 2. Jordan conducted risk audit. Evaluate 3 risk situations and update risk register.

questions.question: Weather insurance created 2-week claim processing delay. What type of risk?

feedback.correct: Correct! SECONDARY RISK—insurance response created 2-week processing delay that didn't exist before purchasing insurance.
feedback.incorrect: SECONDARY RISK is caused by implementing a risk response. Insurance (response) created processing delay risk that didn't exist before.

questions.question: Backup supplier contract reduced risk 30% → 10%. How to update register?

options.text: Update rating 30% → 10%, note 10% RESIDUAL RISK, continue monitoring

feedback.correct: Perfect! Update rating to reflect reduced probability, note RESIDUAL RISK (10% remains), continue monitoring. Never close risks prematurely.
feedback.incorrect: Update rating 30% → 10%, note 10% RESIDUAL RISK (remains after response), continue monitoring. Backup contract reduces but doesn't eliminate supplier risk.

questions.question: Labor strike risk emerged (NOT in original register). What type and response?

options.text: NEW RISK, implement WORKAROUND (negotiate with union, contingency staffing)

feedback.correct: Correct! NEW RISK emerged during execution (not identified in planning). WORKAROUND needed—negotiate with union, prepare contingency staffing. No contingency plan exists.
feedback.incorrect: NEW RISK emerges during execution (wasn't in original register). No contingency plan exists—implement WORKAROUND: negotiate with union, prepare contingency staffing.

screens.title: Risk Monitoring Mastery
screens.summary: Risk monitoring is CONTINUOUS: track identified risks, identify new risks, evaluate response effectiveness, update risk register weekly. Distinguish residual (remains after response), secondary (caused by response), new (emerges during execution). Trigger contingency plans when thresholds exceeded. Implement workarounds when risks weren't anticipated or responses fail.
takeaways: Risk monitoring: Continuous, integrated into weekly status meetings + monthly audits
Residual risk: Remains after response (5% supplier failure despite contract)
Secondary risk: Caused by response (hedging creates cancellation fee)
New risk: Emerges during execution (competitor opens)
Contingency plan: Pre-defined, triggered when threshold hit (staffing >50%)
Workaround: Unplanned response to unanticipated risks or failed responses
Risk register: Living document, updated weekly with new ratings, closed risks, lessons learned

artifacts.title: Updated Risk Register
artifacts.description: New ratings, closed risks, residual/secondary risks, lessons learned

artifacts.title: Risk Trend Dashboard
artifacts.description: Probability/impact changes over time, risk trajectory analysis

characterClosing.text: You've mastered risk monitoring. Risks don't stay static—they evolve, new ones appear, responses succeed or fail. Continuous monitoring with weekly updates keeps you ahead of surprises.
